SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words, phrases, figurative language, and academic and content-specific words.
Content: The phrase “change before your very eyes” in paragraph 8 suggests that clouds

A.Choice: can only be seen up close

C.Choice: can make it difficult for you to see

D.Choice: can become different while you watch

SubTopics: Explain how claims in a text are supported by relevant reasons and evidence.
Content: What claim does the author make about cumulus clouds?

A.Choice: They look like bright cotton balls in the sky.

B.Choice: They form only when it is windy for many hours.

C.Choice: They show that the weather might soon change.

D.Choice: They look pink when they form at sunset.

SubTopics: In literary texts, identify parts of stories, dramas, and poems using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza. In informational texts, identify and use text features to build comprehension.
Content: In which section of the passage can the reader find information about how clouds are made?

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Which sentence from the passage shows a cause-and-effect relationship?

B.Choice: “Other clouds float in the middle, and some move up and down.” (paragraph 14)

C.Choice: “As the day warms up, fog clears away.” (paragraph 17)

D.Choice: “Scientists study clouds to tell what kind of day you'll have tomorrow.” (paragraph 28)

SubTopics: Discuss how the reader's point of view or perspective may differ from that of the author, narrator or characters in a text.
Content: Which detail BEST shows how the author feels about clouds?

A.Choice: “Some clouds travel as fast as race cars!” (paragraph 11)

B.Choice: “You can barely see the road ahead of you!” (paragraph 15)

C.Choice: “... cloudy nights are a little bit warmer than clear ...” (paragraph 29)

D.Choice: “... you are sure to find many wonderful shapes ...” (paragraph 31)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: Which detail would be MOST important to include in a summary of the passage?

A.Choice: Some clouds can look like shapes of animals.

B.Choice: Clouds form when drops of water come together.

C.Choice: Clouds can appear on warm days and on cool days.

D.Choice: Birds fly through clouds that are low in the sky.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: Which event would be MOST important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: A man takes care of the lighthouse and uses a small key to start its light.

B.Choice: A boat greets the lighthouse in the day but the lighthouse does not answer.

C.Choice: A terrible storm comes in the night and the bridge reminds the lighthouse why it is needed.

D.Choice: A group of workers come to the Hudson River and begin digging and building along the shore.

SubTopics: In literary texts, identify parts of stories, dramas, and poems using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza. In informational texts, identify and use text features to build comprehension.
Content: How are the details in paragraphs 1 through 6 important to the story?

A.Choice: The paragraphs explain the main problem to be solved in the story.

B.Choice: The paragraphs introduce the setting and the main character of the story.

C.Choice: The paragraphs show why later events will come to happen in the story.

D.Choice: The paragraphs hint at how the characters will change over time in the story.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: How does the building of the great gray bridge affect the little red lighthouse?

A.Choice: The bridge makes the lighthouse feel like it is not useful anymore.

B.Choice: The bridge makes the lighthouse feel happy to have help with its job.

C.Choice: The bridge shows the lighthouse new ways to help the people of the city.

D.Choice: The bridge blocks out the light of the lighthouse so it is not seen by boats.

SubTopics: Explain how claims in a text are supported by relevant reasons and evidence.
Content: The great gray bridge believes that the little red lighthouse

A.Choice: can help it send lights into the air

B.Choice: should be moved to a different place

C.Choice: is too small to be helpful in an emergency

D.Choice: must continue to do its job for the boats

SubTopics: Recognize genres and make connections to other texts, ideas, cultural perspectives, eras, personal events, and situations.
Content: Lighthouses are important because they guide boats. They can help keep boats safe when weather is bad or water is dangerous. Which detail best shows how this idea connects to the events in the story?

A.Choice: “All the way from Lake Tear of the Clouds, high up in the mountains, came the Hudson River.” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “Now the boats on the river talked to the little red lighthouse as they passed.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “He took off the thick white cap that let it sleep by day. He turned on the gas with a funny small black key.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “The boats saw the light and were safe. The boats saw it, and they kept to the channel.” (paragraph 12)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: What theme is BEST supported by paragraphs 17 through 25 of “Excerpt from The Little Red Lighthouse and the Great Gray Bridge”? Use TWO details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In “Excerpt from The Little Red Lighthouse and the Great Gray Bridge,” why does the little red lighthouse feel proud? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: Which sentence BEST shows a theme of the story?

A.Choice: Goals can be reached through hard work.

B.Choice: Good things happen to people who tell the truth.

C.Choice: Trusting what others do can be rewarding.

D.Choice: The happiest moments in life are those spent with family.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words, phrases, figurative language, and academic and content-specific words.
Content: What does the word “muses” mean as it is used in paragraph 2?

SubTopics: Discuss how the reader's point of view or perspective may differ from that of the author, narrator or characters in a text.
Content: In paragraph 3 of the story, whose thoughts are being shown?

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Read these sentences from paragraph 20.
:ibox:Molly screws up her mouth. She sticks out her tongue to taste just a little.
Which sentence BEST explains why Molly acts this way?

A.Choice: She is certain that the applesauce will win the blue ribbon.

B.Choice: She thinks that the applesauce will taste bad.

C.Choice: She is angry at Sam for putting his apples in the applesauce.

D.Choice: She wants to try the applesauce before Sam tries it.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: Which quote from the story BEST shows that Molly has learned a lesson?

A.Choice: “Molly sighs. She hopes Sam will stay out of the way.” (paragraph 10)

B.Choice: “'They're beauties,' Mom says, and Molly smiles with pride.” (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: “We may even have a chance at that blue ribbon this year.” (paragraph 21)

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Which sentence BEST shows how Molly's feelings about Sam change in the story?

A.Choice: “It's Sam, her messy little cousin who lives next door.” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “ 'Go pick apples over there,' Molly snaps.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “ 'No!' Molly cries, reaching into the pot to pull out Sam's apples.” (paragraph 14)

D.Choice: “Who would have known that you had the missing ingredient?” (paragraph 22)

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In “Excerpt from Hide with the Ladybugs,” how does paragraph 5 connect to paragraph 6? Use TWO details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Recognize genres and make connections to other texts, ideas, cultural perspectives, eras, personal events, and situations.
Content: The cold can be dangerous for animals, so they find ways to stay safe in bad weather. How does “Excerpt from Hide with the Ladybugs” develop this idea? Use TWO details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Explain how specific illustrations or text features contribute to what is conveyed by the words in a text (e.g., create mood, emphasize character or setting, or determine where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: How does the diagram “A Ladybug's Body” better help the reader's understanding of the passage? Use TWO details from the passage to support your response.
